comment_text: Speak simply, Heat travels well through metals, better through aluminum than through copper, better through aluminum than iron, with the same in mind the thing you have not done is use the weighted wire in a below freezing environment. Because at each end of the wire it is conducting heat, at the block of ice it is cooling the wire, this is an active process. The active process in this case includes a constituent that has a temperature above 32f, = test fail "Ice under pressure, must be tested by "RRESSURE" alone." So now you have to test it in a freezing vacuum. Oh wait, you can't. In a proper vacuum there would be no gravity and so this test is dependent and subjective. You could put a couple stepper motors on a really slow pull to see if it melts the ice. But you will need ultra close up high speed to see that it's not microscopic flakes breaking off and melting. As you can see I am extremely suspicious of the atmosphere being above 32f.
the fishing line will cut faster because it is a good thermal insulator

I wouldn't consider that a good demonstration of regelation because I can propose an alternate hypothesis based on known physics.  For example, it could be that the pressure of the string is causing heat that melts the ice and then the surrounding ice is cooling it back down.  I am not saying you are wrong, more that it doesn't highlight that particular process.

This video, along with the skating and "snowball" examples are essentially misleading nonsense. The melting point of ice decreases by about 1C for each 133 ATM of pressure, which is a colossal amount for just a one degree change in melting point.

The wire trick works since at room temperature the block of ice is essentially 0C (rapidly melting!) and the tiny delta afforded by the "pressure" on the wire does decrease the melting point enough for it to melt through the ice. For example, two 2kg weights on a copper wire lower the melting point by about 0.12C! Try the same experiment in a freezer and it would fail completely without colossal mass applied to the wire. Ergo, any example that tries to explain skater's blade pressure on ice as the reason when the ice is below 0C is utterly incorrect. The "compressing snow in your hands" example is completely ridiculous since you cannot apply the tiniest fraction of the required pressure to lower the melting point in any significant way....

Basically, at almost any temperature, ice has a very strange property where the surface is in a near-liquid state and that is by far the largest influence on surface friction.

There's a misconception! Some people think that salt decreases the melting point of ice. Salt doesn't decrease the melting point of ice. Salt melts ice by atoms of sodium and chlorine getting in the gaps in the crystalized water and breaking the bonds between the water molecules making the molecules fall apart and turn into a liquid.

To be technical, increasing the pressure of the ice actually increases the boiling point, the opposite of what is said here. This is clear from the shape of any Heat-Pressure graph for thermodynamic state. Increasing the pressure increases the heat of the ice, however, and the fact that the melting point is higher isn't relevant. It's just worth noting that the pressure does not decrease the melting point like salt does.
